item.title: Skill-Biased Technological Change and Economic Inequality
item.dc:creator: theadmin
item.description:
For the past two decades, skill-biased technological change (SBTC) has been economists’ primary scapegoat for rising wage inequality. The concept that recent technological change, especially in the IT sector, favors those with more skills (that would ostensibly be complemented by this new technology) entails that there will be increased demand and higher wages for those [...]

Read More →
item.content:encoded: For the past two decades, skill-biased technological change (SBTC) has been economists’ primary scapegoat for rising wage inequality. The concept that recent technological change, especially in the IT sector, favors those with more skills (that would ostensibly be complemented by this new technology) entails that there will be increased demand and higher wages for those workers with more skills, while lower-skilled/unskilled labor falls behind. This issue brief examines the validity of these claims.
